content.description: To the right of Timbo the Bimbo. This is the lower half of Warm up that doesn't pull the roof. There are anchors below the roof to rappel on. A very bouldery start to some nice technical face climbing.
content.location: To the right of Timbo the Bimbo.

content.description: Nice face climb up to a roof with long reaches.  Crux is pulling the roof.
content.location: See topos from Camp guidebook atcampeagle.org

content.description: A really short and really fun route. The crux is a dyno to a sloper followed by a razor sharp two finger pocket and then two bad crimps to clip from. The falls really aren't THAT terrible but falling at the crux causes a pretty good whipper.
content.location: Farthest right route on the wall that starts on the ledge over the small fence. However, it is better to start from the ground at the base of the stairs to prevent your belayer from swinging off the ledge.

content.description: Hardest of the top ropes from the start.  Get onto the small ledge and it opens up after that.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: Last top rope north on the wall.

content.description: Like the other top ropes, but with a trickier start.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: To the right of top rope 5.

content.description: Like the other top rope climbs, the crux is at the start since the wall starts with a bit more of an overhang the further north you travel.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: To the right of top rope 4.

content.description: Similar to Top Rope 3 in the the crux is the start with straightfoward face climbing after that.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: To the right of Top Rope 3.

content.description: Another fun easy top rope.  Crux is the first ten feet or so.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: To the right of Top Rope 2.

content.description: This route is a great introduction to outdoor climbing.  Crux is about halfway up, just beneath the small cave-like opening.  Some camp staff call this climb The Triangle due to a faint triangle shaped marking on the roof above the climb.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: Immediately to the right of sport climb Snot Scary.

content.description: This climb was created for the sole purpose of helping campers succeed who were unsuccessful on other climbs.  Artifical holds bolted to natural wall. Great for smaller kids who aren't ready for a natural wall yet.
content.protection: Stainless Steel Shear Reduction Block.  See Camp Eagle Guide for tutorial on how to set your ropes.
content.location: Very obvious due to the artifical holds, but if you still need help, look for the fallen over tree and large bolders.

content.description: Bouldery start with easy climbing that gets harder as you go up. Finish with a few boulder moves.
This tweakie little climb will test your tendon toughness with its small pockets.
Easy ledge filled climb. Following the bolt line delivers the intended experience.

This route should be a standard for every 5.9 limestone sport route. It is the classic Camp Eagle warmup that every climber at camp must be able to do when they start lead climbing on their own.

Start on a shelf then go up from a bomber side pull to good holds and end with a tricky finish with moderate feet. The first big hold is uber polished for good reason.
content.location: This is the start of Say No to Jimi (5.12). It ends at the first set of anchors underneath the big roof. If your face is close to “Jesus” on the roof, you have gone too far.

content.description: Begins with touch technical section with small pockets and continues into easy ledges before a pumpy overhanging finale.
content.location: Immediately to the right of route - The Dihedral.

content.description: Another face climb that ends with a tremendous overhang.
The pocketed start is the crux followed by an easy finish from a large ledge to the anchors.
Starting just below this shallow left facing dihedral, move up and it will open up for you.

UPDATE: A large block of the roof section came down awhile back which greatly altered the route and the existing bolts. Be careful.Outstanding climb that starts with a very obvious dihedral before pulling an interesting roof that requires good foot work.
Easy 5.8 with good holds and many ledges.
content.location: The last climb at the Top Rope Area, before you travel along the cable to the other walls.

content.description: Fun short climb to the left of the Artificial Climb.  Pretty straightforward.

Large area utilized by the Camp for its youth climbing.  Great area with belaying from several large shaded decks.  Also has 7 dedicated top-rope climbs on stainless steel shear-reduction blocks in addition to the sport routes.
